description: Borrowed from Hindi पण्डित (paṇḍit) / Urdu پنڈت‎ (panḍit), from Sanskrit पण्डित (paṇḍita, “scholar, learned man, teacher, philosopher”).

entries.meaning: An expert in a particular field, especially as called upon to provide comment or opinion in the media; a commentator, a critic. [from 19th c.]
examples: This week we introduce Jenny Walker, who will be The Observer's expert pundit for the duration of the World Cup.

entries.meaning: A learned person in India; someone with knowledge of Sanskrit, philosophy, religion and law; a Hindu scholar. [from 17th c.]
examples: Pundits in black gowns, with spectacles on their noses and undigested wisdom in their insides; bearded headmen of the wards; [...] all these people and more also you might find in the white room.

entries.meaning: (historical) A native surveyor in British India, trained to carry out clandestine surveillance beyond British borders.
examples: At every hundredth pace the Pundit would automatically slip one bead. Each complete circuit of the rosary thus represented ten thousand paces.
